title: Deuteronomy Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Deuteronomy chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Deuteronomy Chapter 15.

questions.question: How often is the release to be made according to Deuteronomy 15:1?
options: Every seven years
Every five years
Every ten years
Every year
questions.correctAnswer: Every seven years
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:1 states that at the end of every seven years, a release shall be made.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 15:2, who shall a creditor release their debt to?
options: His neighbour
A stranger
The king
The priest
questions.correctAnswer: His neighbour
questions.explanation: The verse says every creditor that lends to his neighbour shall release the debt, as it is called the LORD'S release.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 15:3 states that a creditor may exact debts again from a brother.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:3 states that a creditor may exact debts again from a foreigner but shall release debts owed by a brother.

questions.question: What will happen if there are no poor among the people, according to Deuteronomy 15:4?
options: The LORD will greatly bless them
They will be cursed
They will lose their land
They will be taxed more
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will greatly bless them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:4 says the LORD shall greatly bless the people in the land if there shall be no poor among them.

questions.question: What must one do to receive the blessing mentioned in Deuteronomy 15:5?
options: Carefully hearken to the voice of the LORD and observe His commandments
Offer sacrifices daily
Build a temple
Fast every week
questions.correctAnswer: Carefully hearken to the voice of the LORD and observe His commandments
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:5 emphasizes that obedience to the LORD's voice and commandments is required for blessing.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 15:6 promises that the LORD will bless you so that you will:
options: Lend to many nations and not borrow
Borrow from many nations
Be enslaved to many nations
Lose your inheritance
questions.correctAnswer: Lend to many nations and not borrow
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states you shall lend unto many nations but shall not borrow.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 15:7, how should you treat a poor brother within your gates?
options: Do not harden your heart or shut your hand
Ignore him
Charge him interest
Send him away
questions.correctAnswer: Do not harden your heart or shut your hand
questions.explanation: Verse 7 instructs not to harden your heart or shut your hand against a poor brother.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Deuteronomy 15:8 says, 'But thou shalt open thine hand wide unto him, and shalt surely lend him ______ for his need.'
options: sufficient
nothing
a little
interest
questions.correctAnswer: sufficient
questions.explanation: The verse commands to lend him sufficient for his need, showing generosity.

questions.question: What is warned against in Deuteronomy 15:9 regarding the year of release?
options: Having an evil eye and refusing to give to the poor
Giving too much to the poor
Ignoring the release year
Borrowing money
questions.correctAnswer: Having an evil eye and refusing to give to the poor
questions.explanation: Verse 9 warns against having a wicked heart thinking the year of release excuses withholding help.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 15:10 encourages giving to the poor with a grieved heart.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 10 says to give without a grieved heart because the LORD will bless you for it.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 15:11, why should you open your hand wide to your poor and needy brother?
options: Because the poor shall never cease out of the land
Because it is a law of the king
To gain wealth
To avoid taxes
questions.correctAnswer: Because the poor shall never cease out of the land
questions.explanation: Verse 11 explains that poverty will always exist, so generosity is commanded.

questions.question: How long must an Hebrew servant serve before being set free, according to Deuteronomy 15:12?
options: Six years
Seven years
Ten years
Three years
questions.correctAnswer: Six years
questions.explanation: Verse 12 states that after six years of service, the Hebrew servant shall be set free in the seventh year.

questions.question: When sending a servant free, what does Deuteronomy 15:13 command you to do?
options: Not let him go away empty
Give him a farewell party
Let him take all your goods
Send him away with nothing
questions.correctAnswer: Not let him go away empty
questions.explanation: Verse 13 commands that the freed servant must be furnished liberally and not sent away empty.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 15:16-17 explains that if a servant chooses to stay, a token is pierced through his ear.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 describe the servant's voluntary lifetime service marked by an awl through the ear.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 15:19, what must be done with all the firstling males of the herd and flock?
options: Sanctify them unto the LORD
Sell them
Eat them immediately
Give them to servants
questions.correctAnswer: Sanctify them unto the LORD
questions.explanation: The verse instructs to sanctify all firstling males to the LORD and not to work with them.

medium.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Deuteronomy Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 15 teach us about generosity towards the poor among us?
options: We should open our hands wide and lend to those in need
We should wait until the seventh year to help the poor
We should only help foreigners, not our brothers
We should give reluctantly to avoid personal loss
questions.correctAnswer: We should open our hands wide and lend to those in need
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:7-11 instructs believers to not harden their hearts or shut their hands from poor brothers but to open their hands wide and lend sufficiently, emphasizing continuous generosity toward those in need.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 15, what is the significance of the year of release every seven years?
options: Creditors must release debts owed by their neighbors
All debts are forgiven by God automatically
Only debts from foreigners are released
Debts must be collected with interest
questions.correctAnswer: Creditors must release debts owed by their neighbors
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:1-2 clearly teaches that at the end of every seven years, creditors shall release debts owed by their neighbors and brothers as it is called the LORD'S release, reflecting trust in God's provision and mercy.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with lending money out of fear of loss. Based on Deuteronomy 15, what biblical truth would you share about lending?
options: Lend generously and do not be grieved when giving, for God will bless your works
Only lend when you are sure to get repaid
Avoid lending to prevent financial risk
Lend only to those who can repay immediately
questions.correctAnswer: Lend generously and do not be grieved when giving, for God will bless your works
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:9-10 encourages believers to give generously without a wicked heart or reluctance, assuring that the LORD will bless all the works of those who give freely and with a willing heart.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 15 instruct us to treat Hebrew servants after six years of service?
options: Let them go free in the seventh year and provide liberally for them
Keep them as servants indefinitely without release
Sell them to foreigners after six years
Release them empty-handed without provision
questions.correctAnswer: Let them go free in the seventh year and provide liberally for them
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:12-14 commands releasing Hebrew servants after six years and providing them generously from the flock, floor, and winepress, reflecting mercy and remembrance of God’s redemption.

questions.question: What reminder does Deuteronomy 15 give to encourage kindness to servants?
options: Remember you were once a bondman in Egypt whom God redeemed
Remember servants are your property forever
Remember to discipline servants strictly for obedience
Remember servants should repay your kindness with labor
questions.correctAnswer: Remember you were once a bondman in Egypt whom God redeemed
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:15 reminds believers to be kind and generous to servants by recalling their own experience of bondage in Egypt and God's redeeming grace, teaching humility and gratitude.

questions.question: A servant says he wants to stay because he loves his master. According to Deuteronomy 15, what is the biblical response?
options: Pierce his ear with an aul to make him a servant forever
Force him to leave without compensation
Ignore his desire and release him immediately
Charge him a fee to remain in service
questions.correctAnswer: Pierce his ear with an aul to make him a servant forever
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:16-17 explains that if a servant chooses to stay, his ear is pierced as a sign that he will be a servant forever, showing a voluntary and binding commitment.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 15 teach about the attitude believers should have when releasing servants?
options: It should not seem hard because they were worth a double hired servant
It should be done grudgingly to remind them of their service
It should be avoided whenever possible
It should be a sorrowful and reluctant act
questions.correctAnswer: It should not seem hard because they were worth a double hired servant
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:18 instructs believers not to find it hard to release servants, reminding that their six years of service were worth more than hired labor, promoting contentment and gratitude.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 15 say about the firstborn males of herds and flocks?
options: They must be sanctified to the LORD and not worked with before sacrifice
They should be sold to neighbors for profit
They can be eaten or sacrificed regardless of condition
They should be used for labor on the farm
questions.correctAnswer: They must be sanctified to the LORD and not worked with before sacrifice
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:19 commands sanctifying the firstborn males of herd and flock to the LORD, prohibiting working with them before sacrifice, emphasizing holiness and reverence.

questions.question: If a firstborn animal has a blemish such as being lame or blind, what does Deuteronomy 15 instruct?
options: It shall not be sacrificed to the LORD
It should be sacrificed anyway
It should be sold to foreigners
It must be healed before sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: It shall not be sacrificed to the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:21 clearly states that animals with blemishes like lameness or blindness must not be sacrificed, emphasizing the requirement of offering only what is perfect to God.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 15, where should the firstborn animal be eaten?
options: Before the LORD in the place He chooses, year by year
Anywhere the owner desires
Only outside the city gates
Only by the priests in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Before the LORD in the place He chooses, year by year
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:20 instructs that the firstborn animal is to be eaten before the LORD at the place He chooses, signifying worship and obedience in the community of faith.

questions.question: True or False: Deuteronomy 15 allows exacting debts from your brother even in the year of release.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:2-3 commands creditors to release debts owed by neighbors and brothers at the year of release, forbidding exacting such debts during this time as it is the LORD's release.

questions.question: True or False: The poor shall never cease in the land, so believers must always be ready to give generously.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:11 teaches that the poor will always be present in the land, and therefore believers are commanded to open their hands wide to their brothers and needy, reflecting ongoing generosity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "Thou shalt not eat the _______ thereof; thou shalt pour it upon the ground as water."
options: blood
flesh
fat
skin
questions.correctAnswer: blood
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:23 instructs believers not to eat the blood of animals but to pour it upon the ground, symbolizing respect for life and obedience to God's commands.

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 15 describe the blessings of obeying God's commandments about lending and release?
options: You will lend to many nations and not borrow, and you will reign over many nations
You will become wealthy through stringent debt collection
You will be free from all trials and hardships
You will avoid all poverty in your land
questions.correctAnswer: You will lend to many nations and not borrow, and you will reign over many nations
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:6 promises that if the people obey God's voice and commandments, He will bless them so they will lend to many nations without borrowing and reign over them, showing divine favor and authority.

questions.question: What warning does Deuteronomy 15 give about having an evil thought in the year of release?
options: It is sin to refuse help to a poor brother because the year of release is near
It is wise to withhold lending in the year of release
It is permissible to be cautious with poor brothers at release time
It is recommended to demand repayment before the release year
questions.correctAnswer: It is sin to refuse help to a poor brother because the year of release is near
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:9 warns against having an evil thought that the year of release excuses withholding from the poor, as their cry to the LORD would bring sin upon the lender, encouraging a generous heart.

hard.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Deuteronomy Chapter 15.

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'release' mentioned to occur every seven years in Deuteronomy 15?
options: It acts as a debt forgiveness to maintain social equity among Israelites
It is a festival of harvest thanksgiving
It marks the beginning of a new agricultural cycle
It is a ritual cleansing of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: It acts as a debt forgiveness to maintain social equity among Israelites
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:1-2 mandates a release or remission of debts every seven years to prevent long-term poverty and social disparity among the Israelites.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 15, who may creditors exact debts from even in the year of release?
options: Foreigners
Israelite brothers
Priests
Widows and orphans
questions.correctAnswer: Foreigners
questions.explanation: Verse 3 specifies that debts may still be exacted from foreigners, but debts among Israelite brothers must be released.

questions.question: What condition does Deuteronomy 15:4 place on the possibility of having no poor among the Israelites?
options: The LORD shall greatly bless them in the land given as inheritance
They must offer continual sacrifices
They must build cities of refuge
They must observe the Sabbath strictly
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD shall greatly bless them in the land given as inheritance
questions.explanation: The verse links the absence of poverty to divine blessing in the land God gives them, emphasizing covenantal reward for obedience.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 15:6 mentions that Israel will lend to many nations but not borrow from them. This reflects what broader biblical theme?
options: Divine blessing and Israel’s elevated status among nations
The need for Israel to be self-sufficient
The importance of isolationism
The rejection of foreign alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Divine blessing and Israel’s elevated status among nations
questions.explanation: The verse expresses that obedience leads to prosperity and sovereignty, a theme consistent throughout Deuteronomy and other covenantal texts.

questions.question: What attitude does Deuteronomy 15:7-8 command Israelites to have toward their poor brethren?
options: Not to harden their heart or shut their hand but to open it wide and lend sufficiently
To give only what is leftover after their own needs are met
To ask the poor to work for their sustenance
To refer the poor to the priests for aid
questions.correctAnswer: Not to harden their heart or shut their hand but to open it wide and lend sufficiently
questions.explanation: The passage explicitly instructs compassion and generosity toward the poor, highlighting ethical responsibility within the community.

questions.question: In Deuteronomy 15:9, what warning is given about the attitude toward lending just before the year of release?
options: Beware of an evil eye refusing to lend, as this causes sin
Beware of lending too much and becoming poor yourself
Beware of lending only to foreigners
Beware of lending without interest
questions.correctAnswer: Beware of an evil eye refusing to lend, as this causes sin
questions.explanation: The text warns that withholding help out of spite or greed during the release year results in sin and divine complaint.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 15:10 encourages giving to the poor with what specific heart attitude?
options: Without grief or reluctance
Only after receiving a blessing
Only in secret
Only during festivals
questions.correctAnswer: Without grief or reluctance
questions.explanation: The verse commands joyful and willing giving, promising blessings for such generosity.

questions.question: What is the reason given in Deuteronomy 15:15 for commanding the release of Hebrew servants after six years?
options: Because the Israelites were once bondmen in Egypt and were redeemed by God
Because servants had to be freed to celebrate the Sabbath year
Because servants had to pay back their debts
Because the land could not support permanent servitude
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Israelites were once bondmen in Egypt and were redeemed by God
questions.explanation: The verse connects Israel’s own history of slavery and redemption to the ethical treatment of servants.

questions.question: If a Hebrew servant chooses not to leave after six years, what ritual is performed according to Deuteronomy 15:17?
options: An aul is thrust through his ear unto the door, making him a servant forever
He is given a special garment marking his servitude
He is anointed with oil and given a new name
He is sold to another master
questions.correctAnswer: An aul is thrust through his ear unto the door, making him a servant forever
questions.explanation: The ear-piercing symbolizes voluntary lifelong servitude, a unique Hebrew practice.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of sanctifying all firstborn males of the herd and flock to the LORD as stated in Deuteronomy 15:19?
options: Acknowledging God's sovereignty and blessing over the first fruits of creation
Ensuring the firstborn are used only for temple sacrifice
Preventing the consumption of the best animals
Marking the animals for taxation
questions.correctAnswer: Acknowledging God's sovereignty and blessing over the first fruits of creation
questions.explanation: This reflects a wider biblical theme of dedicating the first and best to God, recognizing His ownership and provision.

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 15:21, what must be done if a firstling animal has blemishes?
options: It must not be sacrificed to the LORD
It must be sacrificed anyway as a sin offering
It must be sold to foreigners
It must be used for labor
questions.correctAnswer: It must not be sacrificed to the LORD
questions.explanation: The text requires that only unblemished animals be offered, emphasizing ritual purity and perfection in offerings.

questions.question: What does Deuteronomy 15:23 command regarding the blood of animals?
options: The blood shall not be eaten but poured upon the ground like water
The blood must be consumed with the meat
The blood should be stored for future use
The blood shall be sprinkled on the altar
questions.correctAnswer: The blood shall not be eaten but poured upon the ground like water
questions.explanation: The prohibition against eating blood is consistent with Levitical laws emphasizing the sanctity of life.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 15:11 states that the poor shall never cease out of the land. How does this command shape Israel’s ongoing social responsibility?
options: It mandates continuous generosity and open-handedness toward the poor
It encourages building permanent poor houses
It suggests the need for exile to reduce poverty
It implies that poverty is a curse for disobedience
questions.correctAnswer: It mandates continuous generosity and open-handedness toward the poor
questions.explanation: Acknowledging persistent poverty, the law requires ongoing care rather than temporary relief.

questions.question: True or False: According to Deuteronomy 15:22, both clean and unclean persons are allowed to eat the firstling within the gates.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states that both unclean and clean persons shall eat it alike, showing inclusivity in this context.

questions.question: The command to open one's hand wide to the poor in Deuteronomy 15 reflects which broader biblical ethical principle?
options: Love your neighbor as yourself
Keep the Sabbath holy
Honor your father and mother
Do not bear false witness
questions.correctAnswer: Love your neighbor as yourself
questions.explanation: The instruction to generously assist neighbors aligns with the core biblical ethic of loving others, found in Leviticus 19:18 and echoed throughout Scripture.

questions.question: How does the practice of releasing Hebrew servants after six years in Deuteronomy 15 anticipate New Testament themes?
options: It foreshadows spiritual freedom through Christ's redemption
It predicts the establishment of the Church
It symbolizes the end of the Law
It prefigures the resurrection
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows spiritual freedom through Christ's redemption
questions.explanation: The liberation of servants after six years typifies the ultimate freedom offered in Christ, as discussed in the New Testament (e.g., Galatians 5:1).

theological.title: Deuteronomy Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Deuteronomy Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of the release every seven years as commanded in Deuteronomy 15?
options: To forgive debts among brothers as a manifestation of God's mercy
To increase wealth by lending more
To punish creditors for lending
To separate foreigners from the community
questions.correctAnswer: To forgive debts among brothers as a manifestation of God's mercy
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:1-2 commands a release of debts every seven years to relieve brothers from financial burdens, reflecting God's merciful character. This principle is echoed in Matthew 18:21-35 where Jesus teaches forgiveness, and in Luke 4:18-19 where the year of Jubilee is proclaimed as liberty. It highlights God's grace towards His people (Psalm 103:8-12; Isaiah 55:7).

questions.question: According to Deuteronomy 15, how should debts to foreigners be treated compared to debts to brothers?
options: Debts to foreigners may be exacted; debts to brothers must be released
Debts to both foreigners and brothers must be released
Debts to foreigners must be released; debts to brothers may be exacted
Debts to both foreigners and brothers must be exacted
questions.correctAnswer: Debts to foreigners may be exacted; debts to brothers must be released
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:3 distinguishes between debts owed by brothers and foreigners, mandating release only for brothers as part of God's covenant community, emphasizing the special relationship within God's people. This reflects the biblical principle of covenantal mercy (Exodus 22:21; Leviticus 25:47-55).

questions.question: What condition does Deuteronomy 15 give for there to be no poor among the people?
options: Obedience to all the commandments of the LORD
Accumulation of wealth through trade
Strict enforcement of justice by judges
Isolation from foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to all the commandments of the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:4-5 explains that the absence of poverty depends on careful obedience to God's commandments, underscoring that social justice flows from covenant faithfulness (Leviticus 25:18-19; Psalm 37:25; Proverbs 13:23; Isaiah 58:6-10).

questions.question: What promise does God give to those who obey His commandments related to lending and borrowing?
options: They will lend to many nations and not borrow; they shall reign over many nations
They will become wealthy and powerful kings
They will have no enemies among nations
They will never experience hardship
questions.correctAnswer: They will lend to many nations and not borrow; they shall reign over many nations
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:6 promises blessing that includes economic stability and national authority as a reward for obedience. This reflects God's sovereign provision (Psalm 112:3; Proverbs 22:7; Jeremiah 29:7; Matthew 6:33).

questions.question: How does Deuteronomy 15 instruct the community to treat a poor brother within their gates?
options: Do not harden your heart and open your hand to lend sufficiently
Ignore and avoid him to prevent poverty from spreading
Demand repayment quickly
Send him away from the community
questions.correctAnswer: Do not harden your heart and open your hand to lend sufficiently
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:7-8 commands compassion and generosity towards the poor brother, reflecting God’s heart for mercy shown throughout Scripture (Psalm 82:3-4; Proverbs 19:17; Isaiah 58:7; James 2:15-16).

questions.question: What warning does the LORD give regarding withholding help from the poor in the year of release?
options: It will be sin and the poor will cry against you to the LORD
You will lose your wealth immediately
Your family will be cursed for generations
You must pay the debt yourself
questions.correctAnswer: It will be sin and the poor will cry against you to the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:9 warns that withholding help in the release year is wickedness and sin, highlighting the seriousness of social justice as a divine mandate (Proverbs 21:13; Isaiah 10:1-3; Amos 5:21-24; Luke 11:41).

questions.question: What attitude does the LORD command when giving to the poor?
options: Give willingly without grief, for the LORD will bless your works
Give reluctantly to avoid loss
Give only after being asked repeatedly
Give secretly to avoid shame
questions.correctAnswer: Give willingly without grief, for the LORD will bless your works
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:10 teaches that giving should be joyful and generous, reflecting God’s own generosity toward us (2 Corinthians 9:7; Proverbs 11:25; Acts 20:35; Luke 6:38).

questions.question: Why does the LORD command that there will always be poor people among the land?
options: To continually exercise mercy and generosity among the people
Because poverty is a curse from God
To test the rich only
To punish the nation for sin
questions.correctAnswer: To continually exercise mercy and generosity among the people
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:11 states the poor will never cease, indicating God's design for community responsibility and compassion (Psalm 41:1-3; Proverbs 14:31; Matthew 26:11; 1 John 3:17).

questions.question: What is the duration of service for a Hebrew servant before he must be set free according to Deuteronomy 15?
options: Six years of service, then freedom in the seventh year
Ten years of service, then freedom
Lifetime servitude
Three years of service, then freedom
questions.correctAnswer: Six years of service, then freedom in the seventh year
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:12 prescribes six years of service for Hebrew servants before release, showing God's care for liberty and justice (Exodus 21:2-6; Leviticus 25:39-41; Jeremiah 34:14; Philemon 1:15-16).

questions.question: What must a master do when sending a Hebrew servant away free?
options: Not let him go empty but furnish him liberally from the master's blessings
Let him go empty as a sign of independence
Charge him for his service
Give him a letter of recommendation
questions.correctAnswer: Not let him go empty but furnish him liberally from the master's blessings
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:13-14 commands generosity upon release, reflecting God's own liberating grace (Ruth 2:8-12; 2 Corinthians 9:6-8; Luke 14:12-14; Hebrews 13:16).

questions.question: What historical reason does God give for commanding kindness to servants and the poor?
options: Because Israel was once a bondman in Egypt and was redeemed by God
Because servants are more holy than others
Because the poor always obey the law
Because servants are family
questions.correctAnswer: Because Israel was once a bondman in Egypt and was redeemed by God
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:15 reminds Israel of their own redemption from slavery, establishing a theological foundation for mercy and justice (Exodus 3:7-10; Leviticus 19:33-34; Matthew 25:40; Galatians 5:13).

questions.question: If a servant wishes to remain with his master permanently, what sign is given to indicate this according to Deuteronomy 15?
options: An awl is thrust through his ear unto the door
He must pay a fee to the master
He must publicly declare his loyalty
He must marry into the family
questions.correctAnswer: An awl is thrust through his ear unto the door
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:16-17 prescribes a physical sign of voluntary permanent servitude, symbolizing covenant commitment (Exodus 21:6; 1 Corinthians 7:21-22; Philippians 3:12-14; Romans 12:1).

questions.question: How does the LORD describe the value of a servant after six years of service?
options: Worth a double hired servant
Worth half a hired servant
Worth only his labor
Worth nothing after six years
questions.correctAnswer: Worth a double hired servant
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:18 highlights the servant's great value, encouraging the master not to feel burdened in setting him free, reflecting God's abundant grace (Luke 17:10; Colossians 3:23-24; Ephesians 6:7; Proverbs 27:21).

questions.question: What are the firstborn males of the herd and flock to be treated as according to Deuteronomy 15?
options: Sanctified and dedicated to the LORD
Sold to the highest bidder
Kept for personal consumption only
Used as work animals
questions.correctAnswer: Sanctified and dedicated to the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:19 commands the firstborn males to be set apart for God, demonstrating His holiness and ownership (Exodus 13:12-15; Numbers 18:15-16; Luke 2:23; Revelation 14:4).

questions.question: Where must the firstborn animals be eaten according to Deuteronomy 15?
options: Before the LORD in the place He chooses
Anywhere outside the camp
Only in private homes
In the fields
questions.correctAnswer: Before the LORD in the place He chooses
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:20 specifies that firstborns are to be eaten in worship at the Lord's designated place, emphasizing communal worship and reverence (Deuteronomy 12:5-7; 1 Kings 8:29; Psalm 122:1; Hebrews 10:25).

questions.question: What stipulation is given about blemished animals in these offerings?
options: They shall not be sacrificed to the LORD
They may be sacrificed with a special offering
They must be sold to foreigners
They should be used for labor
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be sacrificed to the LORD
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 15:21 forbids sacrificing blemished animals, underscoring God's demand for holiness in worship (Leviticus 22:20-25; Malachi 1:6-14; 1 Peter 1:15-16; Hebrews 10:22).
